html: @ArifAhmed1995 I created the room
for the GSoC project and I added @asmeurer in as well.
text: for the GSoC project and I added @asmeurer in as well.

html:
@ArifAhmed1995, prof. Sukumar and I met over skype today and we agreed on the following plan for the GSoC project:

  • Implement a basic prototype in 2D that accepts a 2D polygon and a bivariate polynomial to integrate, and it produces the correct integral, using the full algorithm. We will cut corners when needed for this prototype, e.g. if we need to assume something more about the functions to be integrated, we can do that. The goal is to have something that implements the whole algorithm to the end, but with limited functionality in order to get this done soon.

  • Part of this is to implement some way to visualize the polynomials and polygons and other steps in the algorithm, as needed. I suggest we use matplotlib and the Jupyter notebook (http://jupyter.org/).

  • Once we have something that works, we will discuss:

    • what features are missing in order to have a nice 2D implementation
    • how to extend to 3D
    • what the best API is for both 2D and 3D
    • detailed plan for the rest of the summer

June 30 Phase 1 Evaluation deadline
June 30 - July 28:

  • use the new API
  • finishing up the 2D implementation
  • 3D implementation

July 28 Phase 2 Evaluation deadline
July 28 - August 29:

  • finish whatever is needed from the previous phase
  • documentation / examples

August 29 Final evaluations
text:
@ArifAhmed1995, prof. Sukumar and I met over skype today and we agreed on the following plan for the GSoC project:

* Implement a basic prototype in 2D that accepts a 2D polygon and a bivariate polynomial to integrate, and it produces the correct integral, using the full algorithm. We will cut corners when needed for this prototype, e.g. if we need to assume something more about the functions to be integrated, we can do that. The goal is to have something that implements the whole algorithm to the end, but with limited functionality in order to get this done soon.

* Part of this is to implement some way to visualize the polynomials and polygons and other steps in the algorithm, as needed. I suggest we use matplotlib and the Jupyter notebook (http://jupyter.org/).

* Once we have something that works, we will discuss:
  - what features are missing in order to have a nice 2D implementation
  - how to extend to 3D
  - what the best API is for both 2D and 3D
  - detailed plan for the rest of the summer

June 30 Phase 1 Evaluation deadline
June 30 - July 28:

* use the new API
* finishing up the 2D implementation
* 3D implementation

July 28 Phase 2 Evaluation deadline
July 28 - August 29:

* finish whatever is needed from the previous phase
* documentation / examples

August 29 Final evaluations

html: @ArifAhmed1995 don't forget to write a blog post today
text: @ArifAhmed1995 don't forget to write a blog post today

html: @certik The prototype for the 2D use case is working now. I'm just cleaning up a code a bit and writing some documentation. I'll surely update the PR and write the blog post by tonight.

html: Perfect, good job @ArifAhmed1995 !

This is the PR : sympy/sympy#12673
Currently the 2D prototype is implemented. Next step is to discuss the final 2D API and how to extend to 3D.
